content.body: Hixie: can an unquoted attribute value contain a solidus?
ah, I guess it can
nm
Wow. Lovely weather.
wasn't the margins on <section> and company zcorpan's idea
document.getItems() is a pretty generic name, hope it doesn't lead to confusion
zcorpan: oh. urm. It's not obvious to me what h1 I should put there on the body root. I'd rather not have anything.
hendry: you could wrap the <article> around the "Spanish sensibilities" section
zcorpan: true
hendry: "Archives Links" seems like it shouldn't be a heading, maybe <nav>
why does this document talk about MIME types instead of media types:
http://dev.w3.org/html5/html-author/
also, I notice this:
http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/video.html#media-types
which has a section called "media types" and then talkes about MIME types
hmm, this also seems to use the two interchangeably:
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html

are these oversights, or is there some specific distinction the working group is intenting to highlight? sorry if I'm missing anything obvious, this is just a drive-by comment after skimming some linked from intertwingly.net

wow — [[That’s where we are with HTML. If we were designing a spec from scratch, it would look much like XHTML 2, which I described elsewhere as “a beautiful specification of philosophical purity that had absolutely no resemblance to the real world”, and which was aborted by the W3C last week.]] — no comment required; it practically satires itself
nslater: Just editorial inconsistency.
gsnedders, you're now an admin for the whatwg blog
starts carrying out his plan for world domination
gsnedders, where exactly did that spammer inject that crap into?
Lachy: footer
in the template?
I'll just restore that from backup
Lachy: Yeah, the footer.
Lachy: I could just delete it from the admin panel :P
I can just as easily restore the entire template directory, so we don't miss anything
crap. The most recent backup has it too. Looks like we were hit a while ago without anyone noticing
I just installed a fresh copy of the default kubrik theme
excitingly finds a trivial way to make a .ttf file that crashes Opera on OS X, but seemingly no other browsers and no other OSes
wonders where crashes reported via Opera's magical popup error-reporting dialog box go to
the internal BTS
damn, I think the WP-Cache plugin is making it harder to erradicate the spam :-(
I just need to figure out how to force it to invalidate the cache
done
takkaria: Hmm, I guess it's a part of the BTS that I can't see
Philip`: I'm guessing as much, anyway
takkaria: Oh, okay
takkaria: Where in BTS? I've never seen them.
I guess Desktop team though anyway
Hixie, I just changed my SSH keys for everything recently. I suppose I could also change the password, but I will have to look up what it is and find out how to change it
gsnedders/Philip`: hm, I may be mistaken then
Hixie, to prevent that from happening again, I made all of the template directories non-writable
so if anyone ever wants to edit the templates, ask me first
nslater: fixed the "media types" section title; where else are they used interchangeably?
Lachy: thanks, good work
Hixie: hey, well just poked around whatever documents I could find in google, and I seem to find both being used. shouldn't "media type" be the one you use? MIME is old, and for email. right?

"An Internet media type,[1] originally called a MIME type after MIME and sometimes a Content-type after the name of a header in several protocols whose value is such a type, is a two-part identifier for file formats on the Internet." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_media_type

nslater: the term "media type" is also used for things like "screen" vs "tv" vs "braille" so it would be confusing to (continue to) call MIME types "media types", so that's why we try to use "MIME types" for those
(MIME types don't really talk about "media" per se so the term "media type" is very misleading)

Hixie: that's an interesting point, but at this stage, I think the generally accepted name is media type and it would seem weird to ignore that, especially if that introuces nomenclature discrepencies with the rest of the W3C cannon. is it really that much of an issue? I'm guessing that its meaning can be accurately infered from context. you're not likely to talk about Internet Media Types and @media types in the same sections
nslater: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#the-source-element talks about media types and MIME types in adjacent normative paragraphs
heh, that was quick!
checks
(though it tries to avoid the term "media type" altogether to reduce confusion for precisely this reason)
wow, that document has caused firefox to grey out under gnome!
oh let me send you a link to the multipage version
hold on
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/video.html#the-source-element

hmm, if "media type" was hyperlinked each time, like I see "media resource" is, would that not help? I'm actually strugling to see the other use of media type in this section. can you give me a bit of text to search for?

"The media  attribute gives the intended media type of the media resource, to help the user agent determine if this media resource is useful to the user before fetching it. Its value must be a valid media query."
.. I think that's the bit
Right, the type attribute is a MIME type, the media attribute is a media query.
which could be reworded to "The media  attribute gives the intended type of the media resource" maybe? dunno
"media resource"?
it's the media type of the resource
i.e. whether it's intended for screen, or projection, or whatever
I just copied that from the document
(the hyperlinking solution would fail in the print copy)
"The media attribute gives the intended media type of the media resource"
to:
"The media attribute gives the intended type of the media resource"
what kind of type?
media type? MIME type? codec type?
hmm..
anyway. the long and short of it is the word "media type" is being used to mean, well, the kind of media, and the word MIME type is being used for MIME types
because that avoids the confusion
at least a little
i can mention this explicitly in the terminology section if you like
I notice that IANA uses both at the same time, which really helps:
http://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/
heh
Hixie: yeah, that might be a good idea
both these documents use "media type" as a section header fwiw:
http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/video.html#media-types
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html
there may be more, I didn't check
the TR page is obsolete, don't worry about that
sure
the only remaining mention of "media type" in the other one is talking about media types
not mime types
okay cool
thanks for the feedback too, didn't know if irc was appropriate for minor comments
it's ok, e-mail is preferred if you want it to definitely be responded to :-)
:p
(You might have to wait three years for the response, though)
i think my record is about 4 years
nowadays it tends to be about a month
nslater: ok added a paragraph to the intro section; let me know if it can be improved.
Hixie: what URI should I check?
the one you posted
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html
bottom of this section: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/infrastructure.html#resources
(these pages are all just different views on the same document i edit)
(personally i prefer the whatwg one because it has nicer styles and has some scripted aids, but it's all the same content)
Hixie: looks good to me
cool
thanks
is not under any impression that "MIME type" is an obsolete term
GPHemsley: it's not obsolete, but it is (or was originally) specific to email, it's use as co-opted by WebArch has largely been replaced with "Internet media type"
I don't think I've ever heard that term before this conversation
well, you learn something new every day! ;)
:P
